summary: Billy Beane (Brad Pitt), general manager of the Oakland A's, one day has an epiphany: Baseball's conventional wisdom is all wrong. Faced with a tight budget, Beane must reinvent his team by outsmarting the richer ball clubs. Joining forces with Ivy League graduate Peter Brand (Jonah Hill), Beane prepares to challenge old-school traditions. He recruits bargain-bin players whom the scouts have labeled as flawed, but have game-winning potential. Based on the book by Michael Lewis.

reviews.content: Watching this for the first time tonight. Yes, 12 years after its release. A mediocre movie at best. Hill and Hoffmann, yes. Pitt, no. I want to like him as an actor, but outside of Ocean's Eleven, he's flat, emotionless and boring in every role, including this one.

Moneyball" is a cinematic masterpiece that tells the true story of how data-driven decision-making changed the game of baseball forever. The film is a perfect blend of sports drama, human emotion, and analytical insight, with Brad Pitt giving a standout performance as the determined and visionary general manager Billy Beane. The script is razor-sharp, with witty dialogue and memorable scenes that keep you engaged from beginning to end. Director Bennett Miller does an excellent job of balancing the intricacies of baseball strategy with the personal lives of the characters, creating a movie that is both informative and heartwarming. The supporting cast is also excellent, with standout performances by Jonah Hill and Philip Seymour Hoffman. Overall, "Moneyball" is a must-watch for sports fans, data enthusiasts, and anyone who appreciates great filmmaking.

The personal intersections of Beane's struggle to change how baseball is played feel scattered and tenuous compared to the struggle itself, but what a struggle it is. Its telling is all the more bold for keeping the game itself at arm's length, as Beane himself superstitiously does ("it's hard not to romanticize the game"), and placing the focus squarely on the offices and locker rooms where his work unfolds.

Released in 2011, "Moneyball" was directed by Bennett Miller as well as starring famous actors such as Brad Pitt and Jonah Hill. The highly rated movie was based off a very famous season that the Oakland Athletics had in 2003. The making of this film involved a very well though plot which was easy to understand and unravel in the viewers mind, a relatively high budget, fan favorite actors such as Chris Pratt, Brent Jennings, Phillip Seymour Hoffman, and Brad Pitt and Jonah Hill who were nominated for the Academy Award for Best Actor and Best Supporting Actor, respectively. 
Moneyball begins at the end of their 2002 season where they lost to the Yankees after being two games up in the World Series. Following that season the Oakland Athletics had three of their so called "irreplaceable" players wanting to leave, to any other team in the MLB they would be able to extend their contract, but the Athletics had the smallest budget in the entire MLB. To put in perspective the A's had a 41 million dollar budget compared to the New York Yankees's budget of 125 million. This created a lot of internal problems that Brad Pitt (Billy Beane) had to face as the general manager. During one of his proposals to the Boston Red Sox to try and replace one of his key players, "Billy" kept dropping his offer for one of the players that they had, the offers seemed to be a steal, but the general manager kept taking advice from what seemed like a loser in the back of the room. After "Billy" left the meeting empty handed he found the guy and eventually asked him to come work for the A's, with the hope of making a huge impact to the success of the A's, his name was Jonah Hill (Peter Brand). Once they teamed up the movie becomes very interesting in the decisions and involvements that they make in order to help the team become successful. 
For a movie released in 2011, I was pleasantly surprised with the cinematography. There were moments that weren't as good as others but overall it was very good. The acting was very good apart from the amount of facial expressions Brad Pitt makes throughout the movie. The plot for the first hour and a half was very good until it got to the end, then it started to drag a bit. My favorite part about the whole movie was the way that they introduced the main characters in the movie, the thought that went into introducing the third main character was extremely creative. There were very creative flashbacks leading the viewer to understand multiple plots and a history of the main character which helped develop the story in a clearer way. 
Moneyball taught me that even if you don't have much you can still make the most of it and enjoy what you have. It also begs the point that if you work hard enough for something and have a strong enough desire you can achieve anything that you put your mind to. Billy Beane is a perfect example of what hard work and dedication leads to. 
In conclusion, Moneyball is a great movie. I recommend it to people who enjoy sports or enjoy watching a good movie with a very well thought plot. People who would not enjoy this movie, are those who do not understand baseball at all, or don't have the time to sit down for two hours to watch a movie. Overall the plot, the acting, the production, and the story lead to a four out of five star rating.

Moneyball covers the real life story of Oakland A's manager Billy Beane and his implementation of the then controversial sabermetrics to the game of baseball during the 2002 MLB season to stay competitive after losing key players and being given no budget to court new ones. The dialogue and acting are phenomenal with humor that often lands. The minimal soundtrack is memorable and the sound design itself is strong. It's not without flaws, mainly the story jump cutting a little too much and flash back sequences to Billy's time as a player not greatly implemented. Still, these flaws are for the most part, minor and should not steer one away from what is a solid sports history movie.

The plot of Moneyball opens with the Oakland A's 2001 loss and general manager as well as former ball player Billy Beane left to pick up the pieces. With no budget and the star players being bought out, Billy begins the arduous process of trying to replace them. When coming to discuss trades with another team, he happens upon Peter Brand who is standing in for the real life counterpart Paul DePodesta. Peter introduces Billy to the sabermetrics approach to scouting and the film follows these two as they work against public opinion, coaches, scouts, and pretty much everyone to build a World Series team all while Billy balances a relationship with his daughter as she grows more concerned for his job.

The casting, acting, and dialogue are the strong points of the film, which is good because that's where it focuses generally. Most of the dialogue sounds almost improvised which carries a realism to it. Not only that, it often had me laughing. Brad Pitt and Jonah Hill play near polar opposites and bounce off each other well. Scenes breath and sometimes, they have no dialogue at all, allowing the viewer to reflect. The plot is tight, though this is expected given that it's built off real events. Some may take issue with the inaccuracies to real life, but they didn't bother me personally. The real issues with it come in the form of it jumping rather than transitioning smoothly between scenes. Billy's flash backs to playing in the majors aren't always immediately clear either because of the jump cuts. Still, these gripes aren't enough to dampen my enjoyment.

Sound is excellent. The music is memorable without ever being explosively bombastic. I especially love the closing scene choice of ‚Äòthe show' and how it's used. The sound design itself is more than satisfying. I think I could listen to baseballs cracking off bats all day in this movie.

My end conclusion is Moneyball is a solid entry into the long standing history of Hollywood baseball movies. It's historically fascinating and you don't have to be an aficionado to understand what is going on. While it does have trouble with transitions and jump cuts, this should not be enough to detract from a great movie, especially those who have a love of the game.

One of the smartest sports dramas, and a great film on America's (former) pastime. It's fascinating, funny, and surprisingly deep. Brad Pitt delivers an Oscar-worthy performance here in a role where he gets to bring his athletic baggage with a chip on his shoulder. His Billy Beane is intelligent, dismissive and impatient at times, charismatic when he needs to be, and ruthless when it suits his interests. It's a stunning turn that Pitt handles with movie star confidence. Just as effective is Jonah Hill, in his first serious dramatic role. He does away with his crass vulgarian schtick, and channels his inner meek nerd in a role that allows him to be anxious, tentative, shy, but often the smartest guy in the room, at least when it comes to baseball players and stats. The fine, witty script (by the great Steven Zaillian and Aaron Sorkin) makes the (literal) inside baseball stuff comprehensible. It also eschews the "big game" sports movie formula while simultaneously breaking down the mythos of the game and questioning long-held cornerstones of how you win a baseball game. Director Bennett Miller brings a curious outsider's view to the proceedings, which I loved. Romantic notions of the sport run up against the modern complications of managing and running a major league team. It all adds up to a lovely, engrossing and moving real-life account of a moment when MLB was changed forever, and it's one of the great films of 2011

Moneyball follows the typical bad-team-becomes-good trope that's common in many sports movies. Yet, like Billy Beane's (Brad Pitt) approach, Moneyball takes an unconventional turn.

One aspect that I admired from Bennett Miller is that he also explored the different conflicts that face each character. We see GM's and Team owners pushing Billy Beane to handpick successful athletes that will make the team great. We see each team member's fear that they're past their prime. And we see the emotional toll that this takes on Billy Beane and his family.

This is a thought-provoking movie that doesn't go too far into the statistical details. It keeps things interesting for those with a passionate love of sports and has an interest in the Moneyball story.

Dig deeper and one can find deeper meaning in this story. We can see the shifting realities of the sports world as they move from all-stars to cold statistics. We see the implications that algorithms will have over human intuition and what that can mean for the world. We also see the fall of Oakland after other, more well-financed teams start to pick up and use Oakland's successful method, leading the A's back to underdog status.

When you think of films about sports you usually envision Chariots of Fire (1981) and Rocky (1976), films that deal with athletes specifically. Moneyball manages to show you sports from the perspective of an ex-athlete turned general manager which gives it a different flavor as we see what goes into assembling a competitive team of athletes instead of seeing the events through the eyes of the athletes themselves. The screenplay from Aaron Sorkin, coming off of The Social Network (2010), helps to pep up what could have been a rote story and confident direction from Bennett Miller creates a deceptively deep and emotionally compelling film about an issue that some, like myself, will have no investment in heading into the film.

The general manager of the Oakland Athletics, Billy Beane, Brad Pitt, is still haunted by the fact that his own baseball career never panned out despite having been a highly drafted prospect. He is determined to have his team be successful in the upcoming season. He enlists the help of saber metrics advocate Peter Brand, Jonah Hill, who encourages him to make risky decisions and unexpected decisions that cause the team to pick up talented players such as Scott Hatteberg, Chris Pratt. Although Beane initially faces resistance from the more traditional leadership group that surrounds him the players he had drafted are eventually given a fair shake and experience unprecedented success with 20 consecutive wins. The Athletics go on to be successful and Beane remains with them despite offers from the Boston Red Sox.

The film takes a subject, baseball, that would usually confuse me or just disinterest me and makes it relatively easy to understand in addition to presenting us with a main character we care for in Beane. We see the game as something difficult to understand even from the perspective of people who have interacted with it their entire lives but as Hill's character breaks down why certain players would be good selections we start to understand his logic and are wrapped up in his passion. A lot of the credit is owed to Sorkin whose style can become grating if ingested in high doses but whose talents shine here. Much like The Social Network the sight of older white men in suits arguing in conference rooms is actually cause for excitement because it is where we get to hear some of the juiciest dialogue. The fact that Sorkin lost the Best Adapted Screenplay Academy Award is disheartening but at least he was defeated by the highly talented Alexander Payne.

The performance from Pitt should also not be undervalued as he plays his character with a quiet restraint necessary for us to believe this story. He is a man living with a lot of regrets, among them the disintegration of his marriage, who does not outwardly project a lot of his stress and anxiety and yet Pitt makes it clear that these feelings are there in every forced gesture and tossed of line of passive aggressive encouragement. Of the five actors nominated for Best Actor I would have chosen him because although I do not usually like his work as an actor I think he gives a very good, nuanced performance here that is essential to the film's success and deserves more recognition.

The film is not one of my personal favorites of 2011 as I preferred Margaret (2011), The Tree of Life (2011), Young Adult (2011) and Margin Call (2011) but it is one of the best films to crack the mostly wrongheaded Best Picture lineup of 2011. It's reputation will probably endure as it taps into the interests of sports fans, a rabid base of people willing to support films, in addition to being smart enough to be championed by critics and film buffs alike. When you boil it down to the basics I would much rather people watch this film than Invictus (2009) and The Blind Side (2009), the second of which is an actively offensive and infuriating film.

I would recommend that people see this film if they are a fan of Pitt, like baseball or just generally films that manage to be both entertaining and informative. I would not call the film perfect because there are times when it gets rather dull in the middle but it's a largely worthwhile viewing experience.

Forced to reinvent his team on a tight budget, Beane will have to outsmart the richer clubs. First off, I loved the story. It was a character-driven piece where we were allowed into the mind of each character, protagonists and supporting alike. We get a look into the world of baseball, as the film really does a good job of putting  that harsh reality into perspective. 

Brad Pitt is someone who has been and has continued to impress audiences with his performances. Actually, the cast is filled from bottom to top with amazing actors and amazing performances. The film feels extremely genuine and that's what makes it stand out from other sports films. It takes a true story and brings it to the screen in a realistic, yet entertaining way. 

Honestly, I think even people who aren't sports fans will find solitude with this film. It's a really well written piece with so many layers to it. It's keeps tension high without ever feeling like a thriller of any kind, but it's also really emotional. There's a lot of themes of career, family, and life itself. It's a story that I think a lot of people will be able to resonate with, even if they're not sports fans.

In the end, "Moneyball" is a film that's gotten better and better over time. It's a high quality piece that you should watch if you get the chance. It's definitely one of my favorite sports films and a constant re-watch in my book.

With Moneyball, Bennett Miller does more than tell a soul-stirring sports drama. Set in a Giambi-era Oakland A's, Mr. Miller immerses audiences in a struggling institution's data-inspired revolution that shook the baseball world while shifting the sport's competitive approach. Festering in tension between long-embraced traditions and boundary-pushing innovation, the A's are challenged by shallow pockets and lackluster talent when General Manager Billy Beane decides to question the foundations of scouting logic by adopting an obscure statistician's "sabremetrics" claim that an OBR (on-base percentage) is significantly more effective in assessing a player's quality than an RBI. In this, Beane, played by Brad Pitt, supplants his scouts with equations and causes an uproar in the process. 

Shining as A's General Manager Billy Beane, a former fielder who bombed the majors as a player, Brad Pitt is Miller's underdog innovator trapped in baseball's dated paradigm. Cocky in a high school star athlete sort of way, Pitt is masterfully authentic in digging into the complexities of the divorced father experiencing meaning in his life by redefining baseball strategy. In this sense, the antagonist isn't a person, or even a character, but an ineffective system reflecting American decay and technological renewal. "Is an algorithm more effective than an experienced professional?" is the central question guiding the plot, breeding a relatable range of self-doubt, insecurity, and courage. Thematically, this translates to, rather Darwinian, "adapt or die" -style lessons on the risks of questioning accepted norms in the name of progress. The story may not be sweet, Pitt's Beane discusses the romance of baseball while he ironically is accused of destroying baseball's mythic romance, but Pitt still shares tender moments. This juxtaposition puts Pitt's impressive versatility on full display - he swings from the ruthless GM trading away his players to the vulnerable dad enchanted by parental love. The best part? He does it in a low-key, natural style that makes it seem effortless. Jonah Hill stars as supporting actor, shining light on Beane's doubts and obstacles. 

With a stand-out performance by Pitt and masterful directing by Miller, Moneyball proves an original, beautiful, and insightful take on a data revolution indicative of the times.

Baseball is an unfair game, some teams play in larger markets and have more money to spend on players, such as the New York Yankees.  Then other teams play in smaller markets and have to watch their best players sign elsewhere for more money than they can offer.  How do you replace those players?  And with what money?  "Moneyball" highlights the events after the Oakland Athletics lost the 2001 American League Division Series to the New York Yankees leading up to their loss to the Minnesota Twins in the 2002 Division Series.  
The Oakland Athletics lost three great players in Jason Giambi, Johnny Damon and Jason Isringhausen to free agency.  General Manager Billy Beane (Brad Pitt) can't get an increase in his payroll to sign big players.  The scouts are all quite older than Beane, they are trying to replace those players using the same techniques that have failed before when valuing a player.  Beane knows that firsthand.  In a flashback, he was scouted by the New York Mets and touted as a five-tool player.  These scouts say this is a once in a time opportunity and he has to go all out if he wants a shot in Major League Baseball.  His parents seemed skeptical and want him to take his Stanford scholarship.
On a trip to Cleveland trying to find a replacement for Damon in a trade, he comes across Peter Brand (Jonah Hill), a man whose opinion is so valued by the Indians organization that Beane buys his contract.  Brand convinces Beane that players are judged on superficial means and some are undervalued.  He conceives compiling a team of misfit players on a budget by buying runs.  They base their decision almost solely on on-base percentage.
This sends shockwaves to the scouts and to the manager Art Howe (Philip Seymour Hoffman).  They sign a player who can no longer be a catcher named Scott Hatteberg (Chris Pratt) to be their new first baseman.  They trade for David Justice (Stephen Bishop) for his high on-base percentage and the fact that the New York Yankees will pay half his salary just to get rid of him.
The season gets off to a rocky start starting off at 20-26, Beane starts getting upset with the way Howe is using his team.  Howe is putting Carlos Pena in over Hatteberg.  Beane retaliates by trading Pena away forcing Howe to put Hatteberg into the lineup.
The team improves over the season and they go on a 20-win streak before ending the season with more wins (103) than the previous season with those star players.  Although the film makes it seem like it's due to these sabermetric ideas, the film never even mentions star shortstop Miguel Tejada and third baseman Eric Chavez, pitchers Barry Zito, Tim Hudson, Mark Mulder.  If the season wasn't successful, this never would have been a movie.
It's still a great movie that does a great job making a movie about baseball, that isn't about baseball.  It's about how you compete in a game that is almost rigged for the teams with more money.  The film deduces that you always have a winner with money but then shreds that idea by presenting the story of the 2002 Oakland Athletics.

While Moneyball might seem like an odd cinematic fit, the dream writing team of Aaron Sorkin and Steven Zailian transform the story of the 2002 Oakland A's into something exciting, emotionally-involving, and surprisingly thoughtful. Though the film (thankfully) doesn't shy away from the nuts and bolts of building a successful baseball team, it's ultimately about more than hits, home runs, trades, and general managers. It's about a man sticking to his convictions. It's also about the fickle nature of legacy, especially in sports. And Sorkin and Zalian, as well as director Bennett Miller, make their points in as entertaining a way as possible, and for that, I give them a tremendous amount of credit. I really was skeptical about Moneyball earlier this year, but as things stand right now, it's among my favorite films of the year.

In 2001, the Oakland A's took the New York Yankees to the brink of playoff elimination, only to collapse in nearly unparalleled fashion, losing three straight games (two at home) and watching the rest of the playoffs from the sidelines. Though general manager Billy Beane (Brad Pitt) was largely praised for putting together such a strong team on a payroll that's a fraction of Yankees', he'll have his work cut out for him during the off-season, as three of the team's biggest stars are departed for bigger markets and bigger paychecks.

This gets Beane thinking: Why continue bringing up the league's best prospects only to see them in a Red Sox or Yankees uniform during the peaks of their careers? He decides it's time to rethink the process of building a championship team, and in Peter Brand (Jonah Hill), he finds a mind that's young, smart, and uncorrupted by the old ways of thinking in Major League Baseball. And though there are plenty of growing pains-and a large chorus calling for Beane's head-his and Peter's methods prove quite successful.

For Moneyball's first two-thirds, it's an engaging character study and fun underdog baseball story. The acting is excellent, the film's pacing is right on, and the direction is energetic. Things take a quick change, however, and the film's coda (which thematically reminded me a lot of another Sorkin screenplay-Charlie Wilson's War) adds several layers of depth to the proceedings. Where I found myself involved throughout the entire film, it was the final thirty minutes that had me enthralled. The pace slows down quite a bit, but the film's message is clearly presented and quite resonant.

Moneyball, however, is nothing without Brad Pitt's exceptional performance. He's in pretty much every scene in the film, and he manages to disappear behind the character of Beane while simultaneously bringing a little of his own personality and swagger. There's a little of Rusty Ryan in Billy Beane, but this character has a great deal more to him. Beane's backstory is developed (perhaps not as much as I would have liked), but we see that he really started on this path at an early age, which helps us understand why he's willing to risk so much.

Jonah Hill is a big surprise. One would expect the star of films like Superbad to be full of snark, even in straightforward roles like this. He's not. Instead, he plays things quite earnestly. Peter is a low-key individual and is really meant to help move Billy along. But Hill keeps us invested in him, and though I'm still not sure he would've been my first choice for a role like this, he proves he's got real chops.

The film's missteps are few and far between. I already mentioned that I thought the Beane flashbacks didn't pay off as much as I would have liked. I also thought Phillip Seymour Hoffman was tragically underused as the A's manager, Art Howe. His character, I also thought, was given the short end of the stick, but all those things are neither here nor there. This is an excellent film and, along with Contagion and Drive from earlier this month, part of one of the strongest September movie lineups I've ever seen. If the rest of the fall plays out this well, we're in for a real treat. If it doesn't, expect Moneyball to be a major Oscar contender, for it's a damn good movie and well-worth the price of admission.

Moneyball is a sports movie that is about more than baseball; it's about economics, conviction, our inherent desire to fix ourselves by reliving the past, and making the most of what is undervalued when we run out of options. Even if you hate sports or feel agnostic about baseball, you will find a lot to like about this film.

Lewis fawned over Beane's now antiquated stats and a 2002 draft which looked revolutionary but turned out badly.  The movie also compressed multiple real people into one fictional amalgamation, form what I've read this was because some didn't want to be depicted on screen.  That this movie works at all is impressive, but that it works even better because of all these things is remarkable.  The element from the book that is focused on most is the psychological history of Billy Beane, and how that history prompts his new approach to building a team on the cheap.  The emphasis on the human drama, the need to fix trajectories in life which have veered off course is explored with real warmth and heft, made more so by the sad fact that Beane cannot control this either, no matter how much he wants to.  Baseball is just as prone to frustrating, seemingly absurd sudden turns as anything else in life.  This is especially true of the playoffs, a capricious, tiny slice of baseball which is too small a sample for any math to predict, and which is believed absolutely to define the legacy of any player, manager and GM. The best film of '11 hands down and (aside from 'The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo') it wasn't even particularly close. My thoughts that this is a masterpiece must be taken with a small grain of salt as I am a baseball fanatic who vividly remembers these events happening in real life, but regardless, it is just an extraordinary film. 

As I said, the fact that I remember all this actually happening (down to the details of the trades, the media coverage and the 20 game win streak) adds a great amount of value. All the names, meetings, transactions and confrontations actually did happen, and the fact that its a 100% true story adds to the films value exponentially. 

Aside from my attachment as a baseball fan and its historical truths, the film succeeds on every level simply as a film. The acting is top notch all around. Brad Pitt is absolutely on his A game, bringing the real life Billy Beane to life flawlessly. Veterans like Hoffman, Wright, Pratt and Jennings are all excellent in supporting roles, but surprisingly, it is Hill who steals the show as Peter Brand, the man who was actually the brains behind the Moneyball philosophy. 

The script is spectacular, sticking very close to the book from which it is based. It creates multi-layered characters who just pop off of the screen. The direction is terrific, splicing real game footage with reenactments which are pulled off flawlessly. Its overall execution, cinematography, scoring and story flow are just great.

Another thing that helps this movie greatly is that it isn't one of those typical 'feel good' sports movies. Its actually kind of bleak and does not leave you on a high note, which I respect alot in a genre known for happy endings. It has a very 'The Social Network' sort of feel to it. Kind of brooding and introverted. That isn't to say that its dark by any sense because its actually very funny, but it is seriously taken, and a serious film at its core.

The only negative I can think of isn't a gripe with the movie, but rather its timing as far as where the A's are at right now, and its contributions to building of a false legacy. The fact of the matter is that Moneyball doesn't work. There's a reason the A's won in 2002 and 03, and it wasn't because of sabremetrics, it was because of something called 'The Big 3'; three ace caliber starting pitchers Tim Hudson, Mark Mulder and Barry Zito who were flat out untouchable during their years with Oakland in the early 2000's, including Barry Zito's Cy Young award winning '03. This movie (like the book) hardly mentions them despite their being the actual backbone of the A's winning ways rather than the Moneyball formula. The A's have been to the playoffs once since '03, and at this current time are the laughing stock of baseball and appear to be headed out of Oakland. Looking back on it, a baseball team can simply not be built on these numbers. All of Beane's detractors in the film are completely and unequivocally correct when looking at the whole story, which really dampens the overall message of the film.

Of course these gripes have nothing to do with the film itself which is brilliant and more than rightfully deserving of its 'Best Picture' nomination. While being a baseball fan will most certainly help, it is by no means a qualification you'll need to enjoy this terrific film. Perhaps the greatest baseball movie of all time, and I don't say that lightly.

I'll be honest guys, I don't like baseball whatsoever. I've never really been able to get into the sport, playing or watching, but there are a few baseball-related films among other sports movies that have actually made me go, "You know what, baseball is actually a little cooler than I thought". My favorite of them all is Bennett Miller's biographical sports drama MONEYBALL (2011), in which both Brad Pitt and Jonah Hill (first dramatic role) stars. The film is also my most favorite Brad Pitt movie of all time as well. Based on the nonfiction book of the same title (written by Michael Lewis), Moneyball recounts the 2002 season of the Oakland A's-at a time when they absolutely sucked-and how general manager Billy Beane (Pitt) and assistant GM Peter Brand (Hill) used sabermetrics to scout and analyze players. The A's barely had a budget which is why they had to use this unconventional approach (at the time at least) anyway-nonetheless the A's ended up having a 20-consecutive-game winning streak, an American League record. Alongside Beane and Brand's exploits, the film also chronicles Beane's relationship with his daughter and ex-wife (Robin Wright), though that is a minor part of the movie. The film also stars Phillip Seymour Hoffman (RIP) and Star Lord aka Andy Dwyer aka Chris Pratt.

This movie is stunning-without a doubt one of my top 3 movies of 2011 and I'm surprised that it hadn't won more awards for Pitt, Miller, and Hill. Bennett Miller always brings out the best in his actors. I feel like whenever he makes a movie, the actors starring will get some major award recognition, which is great because it shows just how great of a director he is. And he is not afraid to go with some unordinary choices, such as Hill as Brand or Channing Tatum and Steve Carrell in Foxcatcher (which is set to open THIS WEEK). Surprisingly enough he's only done four movies in total (including Foxcatcher), and I've only seen two. But just from those I'm amazed at how great of a job he did with tone, performances, and pacing. He's a guy that's here to stay in the industry for years to come and I have been a fan of his ever since I saw Moneyball.

Obviously the performances are fucking SPECTACULAR. Especially Jonah Hill. The same Jonah Hill who played the funny fat guy in Superbad and Knocked Up. He completely shows another side of himself in this movie, and I honestly would rather see him do more dramatic roles than comedies. Now don't get me wrong, I do not want him to quit acting in comedies, but Hill excels in drama so well and it was such a surprise in the first place. As Brand he is intelligent, yet inexperienced, and overall his development throughout the film is interesting: he starts as a Yale graduate with "radical" ideas of picking players, and later starts as a prot√©g√© to Beane; by the end of the film, not only had he become Beane's only friend, but Brand was also more competitive. Of course, overall this is Brad Pitt's movie. He steals every single scene in the film (except a few that he shares with Hill) and his portrayal of Billy Beane was astounding. Jean Dujardin won the Oscar for Best Actor that year but I feel like it should have gone to Pitt. Not only is this my most favorite movie of his, but also my most favorite performance. There was never a moment that I saw Brad Pitt-I only saw Billy Beane throughout the entire film. His scenes with his daughter were also magnificent and though the family scenes were a little unnecessary, it was nice to see the more personal side of Beane-him as father rather than a coach. Phillip Seymour Hoffman is awesome as always as Art Howe, the manager for the A's. It is simply so tragic that an actor of such a high caliber had to have passed away, especially at a fairly young age. Chris Pratt stars as one of the baseball players that Beane and Brand recruit using sabermetrics, and I would say that he was fine. Nothing horrible, but he wasn't that prominent throughout the movie anyway.

Now we come down to this incredible screenplay, one of the writers being AARON SORKIN. I don't know how that guy does it, every single one his scripts are fantastic: The Social Network, A Few Good Men, The Newsroom (he's written a script for a NEW Steve Jobs biopic; we can ignore that Ashton Kutcher one). He's always so precise with the dialogue, and though he co-wrote it with Steve Zaillian (Schindler's List, Gangs of New York) there are a lot of his trademarks in the script. One of my favorite lines ever is when Billy Bean is talking to his scouts and he says: "The problem we're trying to solve is that there are rich teams and there are poor teams. Then there's fifty feet of crap, and then there's us." I surprisingly quote this often, but for some reason I always say "twenty" instead of "fifty". And there are so many more quotable lines than this one in Moneyball too. It's a remarkable story overall and although I haven't read Lewis' book, I definitely think they did a good job adapting it to the big screen. Technical aspects are also top notch-this was nominated for Best Sound Mixing of all things too.

Overall, I LOVE MONEYBALL! This movie in general is special in my life because it actually had me interested in baseball for some time (no offense to baseball fans though). But as I said earlier I thought some of the family scenes were a little unnecessary to the film. However, Moneyball also made me realize that Jonah Hill was not a one note comedic actor. He brought personality and layers to the role of Peter Brand and his debut in a full-on dramatic role was extremely successful. Although Hill is revelation, Pitt is the one that steals the movie and probably should have won that Best Actor Oscar. He wasn't fighting zombies or trying to kill Kevin Spacey; Pitt WAS Billy Beane. The character was so distinct and complex compared to several of Pitt's other performances (perhaps not as complex as Tyler Durden though). And that ending... Whoa. For one thing, I can't believe Beane had done what he did, and later: that final scene was a perfect way to end the movie in my opinion. Brad Pitt is not just Angelina Jolie's husband, he's not just the pretty boy-Moneyball shows that he is definitely one of the best of his generation of actors. I highly recommend watching this magnificent film, especially if you are a fan of sports movies or Pitt - 9.6/10

The point I am trying to make is that some people may avoid this film because they think that they won't understand it.  You would be foolish to not try it.  It is a heartfelt story regarding the Oakland A's through a turbulent time of finance issues and change.  The story pulls you in the whole time whether you know what RBI's are or not.  Brad Pitt is fantastic as Billy Beane, the GM who is not afraid to put his neck on the line and try something for the good of the team.  he doesn't care who he upsets or who disagrees with him as he pushes to stay the course for the greater good of the team.  Jonah Hill plays his assistant in the film and is brilliant in his supporting role.  He helps bring the comedy aspect along with him as he tries to make you believe with him that all of these stats that they are using to try and build the best team they can on their budget will work.  It will make you laugh at points and also make you really root for them as you want all of the time, effort, and support that's gone into building it to actually work.  Overall, even if you are not a fan of baseball you should give this a punt as you will not be disappointed.
